answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Sarah,
I have found a few resources from the Knowledge Network that should prove useful.

Pothole Hotline, a case study from Clackamus County, Ore. that describes the procedure of the city responding to the callers reports in a timely manner. The information for the primary contact and website are also provided. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/1516/Pothole_Hotline
Graffiti Removal Program from the city of Santa Ana, California describes the city’s approach to eliminating graffiti that includes a hotline for people to inform the public works agency. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6540/Graffiti_Removal_Program 
A Work in Progress: Philadelphia’s 311 System After One Year is an operational report on Philly311 initiative that discusses hiring, caller satisfaction, type of requests, response time and provides an overall assessment of the program. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/106388/A_Work_in_Progress_Philadelphias_311_System_After_One_Year 
Using 311/ CRM Technology to Improve Local Government Customer Service presentation provides the findings of the ICMA National Study of 311 and Customer Service Technology. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301751/Using_311CRM_Technology_to_Improve_Local_Government_Customer_Service 

You may also consider contacting these jurisdictions directly for further information. More documents on 311 and community outreach can be found under KN topic pages like 311/ CRM Systems, Community Policing, Public Safety. 
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma 
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Sarah Johnson
text: Are there people that can share their city’s experiences using hotlines to take questions and respond to complaints related to construction? Specifically, we are interested in cities that have had several large scale capital improvement projects underway simultaneously that have used hotlines to address citizen concerns about construction impacts. Information about what structure worked well would be very helpful, including questions such as: run internally vs. contracted out; providing recorded information and/or connection to a real person; a voicemail box vs. an operator; promised response time to inquiries; systems for funneling emergency calls or calls of a very urgent nature to another line.
title: Hotline Services
